thread.title: Stanford defense puts clamps on Washington, 31-14
thread.title_full: Stanford defense puts clamps on Washington, 31-14

author: Tom FitzGerald
title: Stanford defense puts clamps on Washington, 31-14
text:
Stanford defense puts clamps on Washington, 31-14 San Francisco Chronicle 4 hrs ago By Tom FitzGerald Without clicking at the nearly point-a-minute pace of the previous two games, Stanford nevertheless trounced punchless Washington.
AdChoices The No. 10 Cardinal had a tougher time than normal against the Huskies’ Pac-12 leading defense but won 31-14 Saturday night at Stanford Stadium to become the only unbeaten team in Pac-12 play.
Stanford’s irrepressible Christian McCaffrey scored two touchdowns in the third quarter, one on a 50-yard reception from Kevin Hogan, to the delight of a Reunion Homecoming crowd.
BOX SCORE: NO. 10 STANFORD 31, WASHINGTON 14
He rushed for 109 yards on 23 carries, caught five passes for 112 yards and had 300 all-purpose yards, 47 above his nation-leading average.
Next Saturday night’s game at Washington State becomes possibly the critical game of the season in the North Division. Stanford (6-1, 5-0 Pac-12) could move into a commanding position in the division if it beats Luke Falk and the Cougars (5-2, 3-1). WSU, picked for fifth in the division in the preseason, beat Arizona 45-42 on Saturday.
Kevin Hogan passed for 290 yards and a touchdown as Stanford beat Washington (3-4, 1-3) for the seventh time in their past eight meetings.
For the sixth time this season, Stanford’s opponent had an inexperienced quarterback trying his hand against a tough defense. Freshman K.J. Carta-Samuels, a former Bellarmine-San Jose athlete, made his first start at quarterback for the Huskies in place of Jake Browning, who injured his throwing shoulder last week against Oregon.
Carta-Samuels didn’t look comfortable in the first half, completing just 3 of 10 passes for 17 yards. But he found his footing in the fourth quarter and guided the Huskies to a score, which he delivered on a 7-yard run. He finished with 9 completions in 21 attempts for 118 yards.
UW tailback Myles Gaskin rushed for 108 yards in 18 carries, becoming the first Huskies freshman to rush for 100 yards or more in three straight games.
Gaskin carried on all five plays on a 57-yard drive to open the second half, including a 29-yard gallop. From the Stanford 14, he broke outside and scored untouched to cut the lead to 17-7.
But Stanford came right back when Hogan fired a 50-yard touchdown pass to McCaffrey. Hogan faked a handoff to Bryce Love before finding McCaffrey on the right sideline, where he avoided one lunging defender on his way to the end zone.
Stanford backup tailback Remound Wright again picked up many of the toughest yards, once even lining up at fullback before leaping over the line on a 3rd-and-1.
It took Stanford just three minutes to get on the board on Hogan’s 21-yard touchdown pass to tight end Austin Hooper. Hogan faked a pitch to McCaffrey and fired to Hooper, who dragged a tackler across the goal line.
Early in the second quarter, Wright scored a 1-yard touchdown to extend the lead to 14-0. The score finished a 90-yard drive, the longest of the season for the Cardinal.
Three plays into the drive, Wright leaped for a first-down on a 3rd-and-1 play. Hogan hit McCaffrey for 24 yards, and McCaffrey broke off a 19-yard run to set up the touchdown.
A 28-yard field goal by Conrad Ukropina to end the first half gave Stanford a 17-0 lead.
The Huskies didn’t pick up their second first down until six minutes into the second quarter. But their defense was as stout as expected, sacking Hogan twice in the first half.
Briefly: With 987 yards in his career, Hogan passed Andrew Luck (957) as the top rushing quarterback in Stanford history. Moments later, he moved past Jim Plunkett into fourth place in passing yardage.
Tom FitzGerald is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. E-mail: tfitzgerald@sfchronicle.com Twitter: @tomgfitzgerald
